newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy's Superga sees return to profit in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Italy's Superga sees return to profit in 1996.

text.p: Superga Spa, the Italian sports shoe company controlled by financial services group Sopaf, will return to profit this year and plans a stock market listing by 1999, vice-chairman Carlo Mammola said.
"This year has been a turning point and Superga will show a profit for 1996," he told reporters without elaborating.
Turnover this year was forecast at 120 billion lire against 104 billion in 1995, with a gross operating margin of 9.5 percent against 0.4 percent.
The Turin-based company said cash flow was 8.0 billion lire in the black against a negative 6.8 billion last year. The workforce had been cut to 172 from 307.

"The financial situation is steady," said Mammola, adding that debt of 70 billion lire did not take into account the possible sale of its French Eider unit and a large unused part of its Turin headquarters.
Divestments, for which there were already contacts, should bring in 30 billion lire, he said.
A widescale reorganisation and product refocusing programme including price cuts on basic shoe models should also bear fruit this year, said Superga managing director Franco Bosisio.
Superga hoped to open up new shops either owned or franchised, reinforcing its presence abroad, and starting production under licence of new lines like sun glasses, perfumes and accessories.
The company aimed for a turnover of 210 billion lire and a gross operating profit of 42 billion lire in 1999.
